pros: Lots of opportunity to be creative
cons: Can be stressful with other events

pros: Benefits, great co-workers. Having passion towards the great good of the University and being surrounded by co-workers who do too.
cons:
Management. It is appalling to have worked in a department with such mistreatment. Knowing the staff feels the same way across the board but no one does anything but protect the manager. There is a key department on campus that is crucial to the growth of the University but has employees flying through by the dozen because of the management. Listen to your employees, they were hired for a reason. The manager is not always right. Stop protecting the very people that are causing even alumni to turn their heads away from their Alma mater. 

It is evident there is not a lot of room for growth internally when you witness many people from within applying for positions to earn promotions and being turned down for candidates outside of the organization. A lot of empty promises upon hiring.

pros: Faculty were willing to help me develop my management skills and implement my ideas, and also let me learn from mistakes. My management skills have improved dramatically from when I began to where I am now, they also taught me the importance of strong work ethic, customer service and satisfaction, and most importantly to never stop learning. They were willing to let me work around my class schedule and let me put my school work first when necessary.
cons: I was required to be very flexible (around my class schedule), because of the different timing of events we would host. I never had much of a set schedule, some days I would work at 6:00AM and other days I would start work at 8:00PM, but overall it was a great learning experience, especially because they would give me the opportunity to make decisions and implement new procedures, and the faculty was always there for advice and support.

review_title: Learned what NOT to do as a future executive
pros: Salary in comparison to other institutions; Excellent faculty, staff, and students; Some of the academic programs are seriously top notch or the only ones of their kind in the U.S.; Excellent Adult Degree Program that appeals to non-traditional students and is doing quite well in comparison to the Traditional/Residential Program
cons: Middle management and executives; Concerned about leadership's vision at times (found there was quite a bit of disconnect between front-line workers and leadership); Silos between some departments made it difficult to communicate and collaborate effectively; Leadership would sometimes be demeaning and disrespectful to subordinate employees; I never received a raise, and was told by long-standing employees that raises were pretty much non-existent (revenue has been a concern as of late)

pros: Overall my time spent working at Northwood University was not wasted; it proved to be a successful way for me to build excellent professional skills and gain an extensive network of Metro Detroit area professionals.  The colleagues I saw on a daily basis were incredible to work with, they were always supportive, and had the drive to create a successful environment.  The students at the university were more than a pleasure to work with, they exemplified the mission and values of Northwood.  Unfortunately this is where the pros end.
cons: Leadership, if you can call it that, lacked in nearly every department.  Transparency and communication among departments and satellite locations needs improvement; this proved evident when leadership at Northwood notified me of a "Merit Raise" just two days before my position was permanently eliminated due to "budget issues".  Not sure why an organization would notify an employee of a raise they received that is based on performance, knowing that their position was going to be eliminated, and with no offer for new placement within the organization.

pros:
They give you a lot of time off
There are some very talented individuals there
Retirement matching is very generous
Free undergraduate education, discount on MBA
cons:
Management sets unrealistic goals
Management set no clear path for success
Management often overrule employees decisions (micro-manage)
Numbers reported to the staff are regularly overstated

review_title: Good benefits and work-life balance.  Poorly executed vision.
job_title: International Admissions Representative in Midland, MI
pros: The staff was very friendly and welcoming.  Was a part of a great small team within the university.  Co-workers were fantastic to work with.
cons: There was a lack of strong leadership leading the various departments.  Managers were nice but need to make definitive decisions and enforce policy and organization goals.  In general, employees had too many responsibilities that made it difficult to focus on their core purpose and do it very well.

pros: Fantastic Benefits and you have lots of interaction with current and future students which can make the job exciting.
cons: Unstable management that does not consider what students are looking for in today's world of deciding what college students would like to attend. Does not offer a work environment that makes you enjoy your job.

pros: Non-exempt staff personal time off at hire, 20 vacation days plus 2 personal days. Additionally, the University closes operations the week between Christmas and New Year's, so there is bonus time off  with pay.
cons:
Administrators are very concerned about their personal agendas and perks. Very little consideration to those at the ground level doing the work.
The Adult Degree Program is run by an incompetent witch and I would never recommend anyone work for this person.

review_title: Love the job, hate the bureaucracy.
pros: Co-workers are always friendly and helpful.  My flexible schedule and tuition reimbursement helps out with my personal needs.  Lots of vacation time. Good health care and benefits.
cons: Undercompensated/undervalued employees. Upper management has no idea what goes on at the lower operating level.  No understanding of the needs of clients/students means money is wasted for no reason.

pros:
Flexible
Students
Good vacation plan
There are some very talented people employed there
Unique business school with massive potential
cons: Leadership- President cannot articulate mission/vision/purpose of the university, just concerned with number of students and enrollment. Operating manager of the Adult Program (University College) is toxic and causes more problems then she is worth and drives out good people, everyone is scrambling, no one know where they are going.  Atmosphere is borderline hostile and chaotic, unlike anything I've ever witnessed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: People were great at the satellite campus in Florida. Unfortunately, that campus was sold. Was a nice place to work. Friendly with good students.
cons: A lot of politics at the home campus in Michigan. Witnessed dishonesty among top management and an "old boys club" system. Disheartening to see and experience. Also not an empowering environment. Low pay for overseas assignments. Adjuncts were poorly treated by management. Full time faculty did not have a voice in improving conditions.  This led to the failure of both satellite campuses.

review_title: It started great.. went downhill from there!
pros: Great Students! Some faculty and staff are genuine and believe in the Northwood Idea. Nice Campus.
cons: The grand majority of the people feel "fake", and wouldn't hesitate to backstab you if the situation calls for it. Management (CEO and former Academic Dean in particular) doesn't care and always try to go the easy route. Not committed to employee development or retention.

pros: Love my coworkers and job. Northwood has a great family atmosphere.
cons: Upper management is clueless and out of touch. My boss knows nothing about their position or what their employees do. I'm pretty sure they don't know what my job actually consists of. Everyone is very reluctant to change and super old school. There is no work-life balance and HR does not care to help.

review_title: Overall good experience, lower than average pay.
pros: Very flexible schedule, allows autonomy to grow personal business acumen.  Some days can entail long hours with many different job functions; however, some days are very light.
cons: Upper management contradicts what the University teaches.  Many business functions within Northwood University are ran as if they are on their heels 24/7.  Also, budgets are often cut again and again to the point where they are running their operations to the bare minimum.

review_title: On a Sinking Ship that has no chance of survival.
pros:
Time off.  You get the entire week between Christmas and New Years Off.
There is also generous Vacation, Sick and Personal Days available to you.
Access to some intelligent business professionals, specifically professors.
Slower Summer because Students are out of school.
cons: The culture is the biggest con to working with Northwood University, specifically in Admissions.  The culture that has been created over the past two years is horrendous.  It's a toxic and cancerous department and company to be involved in.  Personal opinion, turnover will continue to rise while the VP of Enrollment and the current Director of Admissions are employed by Northwood University.  Both of these individuals do not want to hear your opinion or respect it.  They've created a culture where you cannot say a word without getting your hand slapped or taken to the principles office.  Over the past 3 months, over 45% of the Admissions Staff has been given a verbal warning or written up for no valid reason.  The new management is simply trying to show their power of authority by writing people up.  Another con is the nights and weekends.  They expect you to be in the high schools during the day and with families in their home on nights and weekends.  There is literally no work to home life balance, which can cause strife in your own personal families.  Another con is that they have been on a pay freeze and hiring freeze for years. When jobs are posted, it is simply because the person employed quit or was let go, not because they are growing and have jobs that need filled.  I have never found a company with a culture like this, it's absolutely sickening that HR has let this go on for so long.  Take my advice and please do not even consider taking a job with this company because you will regret it.  There is not one person in Admissions that wants to work there, they are simply waiting it out to see if Management changes over the next year.  Management is also very condescending when they speak with you and treat you as if you are incompetent, when in all actuality you are more competent than they are.  They also should stop preaching the value proposition.  Every Admissions Representative was trained by the consulting firm and we do not need a weekly reminder about the value proposition.  We are adults, we can retain information.

review_title: Great Leadership at the Florida Campus
job_title: Adjunct Professor in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: As an Adjunct Professor, I have to say that the faculty that I work with are wonderful. Leadership is very proactive and helpful. Many opportunities for skill development.
cons: A little understaffed due to a university wide hiring freeze. Faculty pitches in to help each other out, but it can be difficult for for time faculty given the large number of Adjuncts.

pros: Everyone is very close together. They all get along great. It was probably the best experience i have ever had at a company.
cons: Pay isn't amazing, they would ideally like you to relocate for most positions. This sucks when you sign a lease elsewhere

pros: I really enjoy my job, just a badly organized and administered place.
cons: Poor, substandard pay, administration has no appreciation for employees' efforts, benefits are not comparable to other, similar positions at other Universities, lack of academic rigor, poor utilization of staff and faculty.  Northwood had a buy-out program recently, many left.  Some left who had 20+ years of service without even a card from management.  A very callous process..

pros: Good Company who offers adult learners the opportunity to earn a four-year degree from a private university on a community college campus.  Staff is very helpful and friendly.
